content.question: Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> slides across a horizontal surface where friction between Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and the surface is negligible. Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is then carefully dropped from a small height above Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, as shown in the figure. Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> sticks to Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and the two-block system continues to slide horizontally together. Which of the following correctly describes the change in speed of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> immediately after Block <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> sticks to Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> ?

choices.label: The speed of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is less because of conservation of mechanical energy.
The speed of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is less because of conservation of linear momentum.
The speed of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is greater because of the conservation of mechanical energy.
The speed of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is greater because of the conservation of linear momentum.

content.answer: The speed of Block <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is less because of conservation of linear momentum.
